Idiom (Tokelauan): E lē mafai ne te tagata e tasi ke amo te motu katoa
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; declarative structure with modal verb 'mafai'
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: No one person can bear all responsibilities alone.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional communal saying from Tokelau emphasizing collective duty.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e leː mafaɪ ne te taŋata e tasi ke amo te motu katoa
First Example Sentence: E masani o fakaaogā te kupu 'E lē mafai ne te tagata e tasi ke amo te motu katoa' i te fono.
Second Example Sentence: Ne fai atu te toeaina, 'E lē mafai ne te tagata e tasi ke amo te motu katoa.'
Third Example Sentence: I te galuega, e manatua ne te tino katoa, e lē mafai ne te tagata e tasi ke amo te motu katoa.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E fua te niu i te fua muamua
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Declarative fixed expression with comparative construction
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person’s future can often be predicted from early signs.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws from the coconut tree — central in Tokelauan life — as a metaphor for growth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e fua te niu i te fua muamua
First Example Sentence: Ko te mātua ne fai, 'E fua te niu i te fua muamua' i te ako a te tamaiti.
Second Example Sentence: E fai mālie te toeaina, 'E fua te niu i te fua muamua,' i te fono.
Third Example Sentence: E fakaaoga te kupu nei ke fakamanatu ki te tāua o te ako i te fanau.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E lē fai fua te matagi e aunoa mā te galu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: There is no effect without a cause.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the maritime life of Tokelau, where wind and waves are intertwined.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e le fai fua te mataŋi e aunoa ma te ŋalu
First Example Sentence: E lē fai fua te matagi e aunoa mā te galu, ko te uiga, e iai te pogai o mea katoa.
Second Example Sentence: Ne fakamatala te faifeau, 'E lē fai fua te matagi e aunoa mā te galu.'
Third Example Sentence: I te fono, e talia te manatu, e lē fai fua te matagi e aunoa mā te galu.

Idiom (Tokelauan): Ko te tagata mālie, ko te tagata poto
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Parallel nominal clause with copular structure
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A calm person is a wise person.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Tokelauan teaching promoting humility and patience.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): ko te taŋata maːlie ko te taŋata poto
First Example Sentence: E fai mālie te mātua, 'Ko te tagata mālie, ko te tagata poto.'
Second Example Sentence: Ne lagona ne au i te ekalesia, 'Ko te tagata mālie, ko te tagata poto.'
Third Example Sentence: E fakamālie te fanau ki te manatu, ko te tagata mālie, ko te tagata poto.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E mou te lā, e lē mou te manatu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Time may pass, but memories remain.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Memories last even when time passes.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Commonly used in remembrance speeches and traditional songs.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e mou te laː e le mou te manatu
First Example Sentence: I te lotu, ne fai te faifeau, 'E mou te lā, e lē mou te manatu.'
Second Example Sentence: Ne tusi te pese, 'E mou te lā, e lē mou te manatu' mō te māvae.
Third Example Sentence: E mafaufau te tagata i te māvae mā te manatu, e mou te lā, e lē mou te manatu.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E iloa te tagata i tena galuega
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person is known by their work.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People are judged by what they do.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects communal Tokelauan values on diligence and integrity.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e iloa te taŋata i tena ŋaluŋa
First Example Sentence: Ne fai atu te pule, 'E iloa te tagata i tena galuega.'
Second Example Sentence: E tāua te manatu, e iloa te tagata i tena galuega.
Third Example Sentence: E masani o fakaaogā i te galuega, e iloa te tagata i tena galuega.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E lē toe fakataulaga te ika kua māvae
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: What is lost cannot be regained.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Relates to Tokelauan fishing culture and the irreversible nature of mistakes.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e le toe fakataulaga te ika kua maːvae
First Example Sentence: Ne fai atu te toeaina, 'E lē toe fakataulaga te ika kua māvae.'
Second Example Sentence: E fakaaoga i taimi o te fakanoanoa, e lē toe fakataulaga te ika kua māvae.
Third Example Sentence: E manatu te tino katoa, e lē toe fakataulaga te ika kua māvae.

Idiom (Tokelauan): Ko te vā o te tagata mā te lagi, e tasi
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Human and spiritual realms are deeply connected.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Humans and the heavens are one.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional belief from Tokelauan cosmology emphasizing unity between heaven and earth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): ko te vaː o te taŋata ma te laŋi e tasi
First Example Sentence: I te lotu, ne fai atu, 'Ko te vā o te tagata mā te lagi, e tasi.'
Second Example Sentence: E mafaufau te tagata ki te vā, 'Ko te vā o te tagata mā te lagi, e tasi.'
Third Example Sentence: E lagona i te pese tuai, 'Ko te vā o te tagata mā te lagi, e tasi.'

Idiom (Tokelauan): E lē māvae te alofa i te taimi
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Declarative clause with negative and temporal complement
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: True love does not fade over time.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in Tokelauan love songs and oral traditions.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e le maːvae te alofa i te taimi
First Example Sentence: E tusi te pese, 'E lē māvae te alofa i te taimi.'
Second Example Sentence: E fai mālie te mātua, 'E lē māvae te alofa i te taimi.'
Third Example Sentence: E manatua ne ia, e lē māvae te alofa i te taimi.

Idiom (Tokelauan): E fano te tagata mā te matagi, a e tu tonu te loto
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Compound declarative clause with contrastive conjunction
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Though life changes, a steadfast heart remains true.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People may change, but character endures.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Tokelauan seafaring heritage and the value of steadfastness.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tokelauan): e fano te taŋata ma te mataŋi a e tu tonu te loto
First Example Sentence: E masani o fakaaogā, 'E fano te tagata mā te matagi, a e tu tonu te loto.'
Second Example Sentence: E fai atu te toeaina, 'E fano te tagata mā te matagi, a e tu tonu te loto.'
Third Example Sentence: E manatu te faifeau, 'E fano te tagata mā te matagi, a e tu tonu te loto.'
